TEI.2.document_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1919: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1924), 3 vols., Vol 1, Part 2, pp. 1264
TEI.2.document_title: George Shannon to Stephen F. Austin, 02-16-1826

barker_notes.barker_summary: Introducing William Haydon and Jacob Fry.
barker_notes.barker_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1919: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1924), 3 vols., Vol 1, Part 2, pp. 1264

text.body:
*div1 type="summary"* *p*Introducing William Haydon and Jacob Fry.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p**location_mentioned*Lexington*/location_mentioned* *date_mentioned n="02-16-1826">Feby. 16. 1826*/date_mentioned*.*/p* *p*Dear Sir,*/p*
*p*This will introduce to you *person_mentioned*Mr. William Hayden*/person_mentioned*, and *person_mentioned*Doctr Jacob Fry*/person_mentioned*; two intelligent young Gentlemen, of pure and exalted moral character, and each of them, respectably connected in this *location_mentioned*Country*/location_mentioned*. They visit your *location_mentioned*Territory*/location_mentioned* with a view to ultimate location, and a permanent residence there, you will find them, in every respect, highly worthy of being incorporated as *person_mentioned*citizens */person_mentioned*of your new and flourishing *location_mentioned*colony*/location_mentioned*; and if pleased with the climate, and soil, and other inducements to imigration, they will draw after them, a long train, of most respectable *person_mentioned*relatives */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*friends*/person_mentioned*.*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*George Shannon*/person_mentioned**/p*
*p**person_mentioned*Stephen Austin Esquire*/person_mentioned*—*/p* */div1*
